metadata.case_name: M. Y. Shareef & Anr. v. Judges of Nagpur High Court

facts.text: Shri Zikar filed application under Article 226 alleging he was citizen of Bharat, Custodian and police treating him as Pakistan national, prayed for interim prohibition against deportation.
High Court granted interim order of prohibition.
On 11th August 1950, at hearing, State raised preliminary objection that Zikar suppressed material facts, petition liable to be dismissed.
Shri Shareef, counsel for Zikar, combated contention, submitted preliminary objection could be dealt without merits.
State filed affidavit on 17th August 1950 stating facts; Zikar directed to file reply by 21st August 1950, which he did.

On 21st August 1950, proceedings: Shareef filed affidavit and copies; attention drawn to para 4, asked if client understood English contents; Shareef said he explained; para 6 uncalled for; remark if inserted for Supreme Court argument; Shareef said stated facts; Naik continued arguments till lunch.
After lunch on 21st August 1950, Shareef sought time to apply for transfer due to observations on paras 4 and 6; case adjourned to 25th August 1950.

On 23rd August 1950, application for transfer signed by Zikar, Shareef and Dr. Kathalay: grounds - observations and references to Supreme Court by Rao and Deo JJ. created bona fide belief of prejudice; unnecessary, no doubt would not receive justice; pray transfer to another Bench.
Preliminary objection upheld, Article 226 petition dismissed.
High Court ordered notices to Zikar, Shareef, Kathalay to show cause why committed for contempt for scandalizing Court via transfer application.

Dr. Kathalay filed written statement 4th October 1950: denied scandalized Court; 40 years career upholding dignity; no animus; bona fide thought could apply for transfer; question of principle on counsel duty; regretted hurt to Judges' feelings.
Shri Shareef filed similar written statement: did not know law prohibited; under impression could apply; expressed regret.
Shareef filed further statement 16th October 1950: grieved at malice accusation; defending honour; admits possible error of judgment causing pain, deeply regrets.

High Court held transfer application constituted contempt; advocates guilty; plea of error not accepted as defiant; regret not apology; sentenced Shareef Rs.500 fine or 2 weeks SI; Kathalay Rs.1000 or 1 month SI.
Leave to appeal refused by High Court, granted by Supreme Court.
On 12th May 1954, Supreme Court: appellants tendered unqualified apology; sincere; adjourned 2 months, direct tender to Division Bench.
High Court on remand: apology not different from original; no prayer for relief; hardly apologetic; not accept as right; would encourage notion of right to acceptance; not remit sentence.
Appeal back to Supreme Court; Dr. Tek Chand affirmed genuine sorrow.

legal_issues.text: Whether signing the transfer application impeaching impartiality of Judges constituted contempt of Court by scandalizing the Court with view to perverting due course of justice.
Whether unqualified apology tendered purges the contempt, warranting remission of sentence.
Whether counsel's duty to client prevails over duty to Court when signing applications containing scandalizing matter.

petitioner_arguments.text: Signing transfer application not scandalizing Court; bona fide belief could apply for transfer; professional duty if client under bona fide impression; no animus; error of judgment; regret and unqualified apology purges contempt.
Misconception prevalent in section of Nagpur Bar about counsel responsibilities; acting in client interest legitimate even if scandalizing.

respondent_arguments.text: Transfer application scandalized Judges to divert justice; defiant justification; belated error plea; regret not genuine apology; no right to remission; acceptance sets bad precedent, blow to Court authority.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Contempt precedents (various English and Indian cases)

court_reasoning.text: Transfer application constituted contempt as scandalized Judges to divert justice; decision stands; no exception taken.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judges scandalized with view to perverting due course of justice.

court_reasoning.text: Proposition: no both justification and apology; apology evidence of contriteness; misconception in Bar that client duty prevails; counsel guilty if sign without prima facie grounds to prevent/delay justice; duty to advise against.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Misconception to be rooted out by clear pronouncement.

court_reasoning.text: Act under mistaken view of rights/duties; borderline case settling principle; not patent contempt; Judges' Supreme Court reference unfortunate; counsel genuinely believed right; defence not contumacy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea of justification not contumacy given Bar impression.

court_reasoning.text: Unqualified apology sincere, repeated; High Court should have accepted post-finding of guilt; condemnation punishment enough; set aside fine.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Apology purges contempt in peculiar circumstances.

holdings.text: Counsel signing applications/pleadings scandalizing Court without prima facie grounds, to prevent/delay justice, guilty of contempt; duty to advise client against.
Unqualified sincere apology can purge contempt in borderline cases settling counsel duties, absent contumacy.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court considered large number of English and Indian authorities to hold contempt; Supreme Court: no application to this character.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Underlying petition for enforcement of fundamental rights and interim prohibition.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed to extent sentence of fine set aside; unqualified apology accepted as purging contempt; strong admonition and warning issued to appellants for conduct.

key_quotes.text: there cannot be both justification and an apology. The two things are incompatible.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle on apology in contempt.

key_quotes.text: counsel who sign applications or pleadings containing matter scandalizing the Court without reasonably satisfying themselves about the prima facie existence of adequate grounds therefor, with a view to prevent or delay the course of justice, are themselves guilty of contempt of Court
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Whatever the circumstances, I do see how much this application for transfer dated the 23rd August, 1950, has hurt the feelings of the Honble Judges and I very much regret that all this should have happened.
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
key_quotes.significance: Early expression of regret by Dr. Kathalay.
